resources.string: In this app you can calculate the capacitance of a capacitor by entering a three-digit (XYZ) code or by entering in a capacitance value to get a code.
Additionally, you can calculate the capacitance of a SMD capacitor by any of the three available standards.
We also include a information page with details, characteristics, and applications of various types of capacitors.
Below are common capacitor codes and their respective values in pF, nF, and µF.
Smaller capacitors often use a shorthand code to fit all the important details onto the component. The most common format is XYZ T VOLTS, where:
XYZ represents the capacitance, read as XY * 10\u1dbb, typically in pico-farads
"T is a letter indicating the capacitor's tolerance"
"VOLTS shows the capacitor's maximum rated voltage"

"Tolerance indicates how much the actual capacitance may vary from the labeled value, usually shown as a percentage (e.g., ±10%). A lower tolerance means the capacitor's value is closer to its stated rating."
Voltage Rating is the maximum voltage the capacitor can safely handle. Exceeding this rating risks damaging the capacitor or causing it to fail.

Capacitors come in many shapes and sizes, each with slight variations on which markings they have. For the most part if the capacitance is not directly marked, a three digit code determines the capacitance.
Tap a capacitor type to learn more about its characteristics, applications, and advantages.

The information provided on these pages has been sourced from Wikipedia. While efforts have been made to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the information, Wikipedia is a user-edited platform and may contain inaccuracies. Please verify details independently if necessary.

Ceramic capacitors are fixed-value capacitors that use a ceramic material as the dielectric. They are typically constructed of alternating layers of ceramic and metal electrodes. The specific ceramic composition determines the electrical behavior and best-fit applications.
With production volumes exceeding one trillion pieces per year, ceramic capacitors are among the most widely manufactured and used capacitors in electronic equipment.
Ceramic capacitors commonly use a three-digit code (e.g., \"103\") to represent their capacitance. Additional markings may indicate tolerance (e.g., \"J\") and voltage rating (e.g., \"2A\").
There are two standard classes of ceramic capacitors (Class I and Class II), each specialized for different needs.
Class I capacitors offer high stability and low losses, making them ideal for resonant circuit applications.
Class II capacitors provide high volumetric efficiency, well-suited for bypass, decoupling, and smoothing applications.
Film capacitors use a thin plastic film as the dielectric, often with a paper layer carrying the electrodes. Different film materials provide unique properties that influence their performance.
Many film capacitors print key values, such as capacitance and voltage rating, directly on the case. If not, a three-digit code is typically used to indicate these parameters (e.g., 104 for 0.1 µF).
Polypropylene (PP) is one of the most common film materials in industrial and power capacitors. It absorbs very little moisture, allowing for \"naked\" designs without additional coatings.
Polypropylene capacitors suit applications like filters, oscillators, and audio circuits. They can also compensate for inductive coils in precision filters.
Polyester (PET) film also resists moisture, enabling uncoated \"naked\" designs. These capacitors are mass-produced, cost-effective, and relatively compact for given capacitance values.
Polyester film capacitors are ideal for general-purpose or semi-critical circuits, typically operating up to 125°C.
PEN capacitors can be larger for equivalent ratings, but excel at higher temperatures above 125°C. They offer strong electrical properties up to around 175°C.
PEN capacitors often provide non-critical filtering, coupling, or decoupling when moderate temperature variance is acceptable.
PPS capacitors exhibit minimal capacitance drift (±1.5%) across a broad temperature range. Their frequency stability (±0.5%) from 100 Hz to 100 kHz is better than many other ilm types.
PPS capacitors perform well in high-temperature or frequency-determining circuits, and can replace discontinued polycarbonate devices.
Some film capacitors withstand temperatures up to 200°C or higher (260°C with derating). They also feature an extremely low dissipation factor, around 0.0002.
These high-temperature capacitors appear in military equipment, aerospace applications, deep geological probes, burn-in testing, and premium audio systems.
Once popular for general-purpose use, polystyrene capacitors offer stable capacitance, low losses, and low leakage currents. They are less common today but still favored in certain designs.
PS capacitors have near-zero temperature coefficient, making them valuable for tuned circuits where temperature drift must be minimized.

Polycarbonate film capacitors exhibit low losses and stable electrical properties, changing by about ±80 ppm across their operating temperature range. However, film supply has been discontinued by major manufacturers.
Historically, PC capacitors were used in precision timing, analog filters, and signal processing under demanding environmental conditions.

Electrolytic capacitors are polarized because of their asymmetrical construction. The positive terminal (anode) must consistently be at a higher potential than the negative terminal (cathode), which is why polarity markings are included. Applying a reverse voltage or exceeding the rated voltage, even by just 1–1.5 volts, can critically damage the dielectric and lead to severe failure.
"The capacitance value is typically printed on the capacitor's casing in microfarads (µF). This indicates how much electric charge it can store, as shown in the illustration above."
Alongside the capacitance, you will find a voltage rating that specifies the maximum voltage the capacitor can safely handle.

Non-solid (\"wet\") aluminum electrolytic capacitors are often the most cost-effective option, especially for higher capacitance or voltage needs. They handle frequent charging and discharging well and tolerate low-energy transients without damage.

Tantalum electrolytic capacitors are used where minimal space or a low profile is required. They offer stable performance across a broad temperature range, making them reliable for compact electronic devices.
Niobium electrolytic capacitors compete with tantalum capacitors due to comparable properties and the more abundant availability of niobium, making it a viable alternative in many applications.

Non-solid electrolytic capacitors appear in most consumer and industrial electronics. Military and space systems, however, often favor tantalum electrolytic capacitors because they meet stricter reliability standards.

Supercapacitors (also known as ultracapacitors) are high-capacity energy storage devices that bridge the gap between traditional electrolytic capacitors and rechargeable batteries. They can hold 10 to 100 times more energy per unit volume or mass than regular electrolytic capacitors, accept and deliver charge far more rapidly than batteries, and tolerate substantially more charge-discharge cycles.

Most supercapacitors have their capacitance and voltage ratings clearly marked on the case. Their capacitance often falls in the farad (F) range—significantly higher than the microfarad or millifarad levels typically seen in electrolytic capacitors.

These devices excel in applications demanding frequent and rapid charging or discharging. Common uses include regenerative braking in vehicles (cars, buses, trains), energy buffering in cranes and elevators, and burst-mode power delivery. Smaller supercapacitors can also serve as backup power for volatile memory, such as SRAM, in various electronic systems.

Mica (or silver mica) capacitors are known for their precision, stability, and reliability. Typically offering smaller capacitance values, they excel at high frequencies where minimal losses and very low drift are critical.

Mica capacitors typically have their capacitance, tolerance, and voltage rating directly marked. They are used at 100 V to 10 kV, ranging from a few pF up to a few nF, and the average temperature coefficient is around 50 ppm/°C.

Key benefits include outstanding stability (due to the absence of capacitive air gaps), a sealed enclosure preventing corrosion of the plates, and efficient use of volume by allowing thinner conductive layers.

Engineers often select mica capacitors for high-power tasks like RF transmitters, electronic instruments, and amplifiers, where cheaper ceramics may fail under heat or high voltage. Silver mica is also widely preferred in high-voltage circuits thanks to its impressive breakdown voltage.

A polymer capacitor (or polymer electrolytic capacitor) uses a solid conductive polymer as the electrolyte. It is considered a type of electrolytic capacitor but with distinct advantages due to the polymer material.

These capacitors feature notably low equivalent series resistance (ESR) and high ripple current ratings. However, polymer electrolytic capacitors often have a higher leakage current compared to other solid or non-solid electrolytic types.
Polymer capacitors may have their capacitance stamped directly on the case or indicated through a three-digit code, similar to other capacitor types.

Polymer tantalum electrolytic capacitors can achieve ESR values around 1/10th that of standard tantalum capacitors with manganese dioxide electrolytes. By using a multi-anode design—connecting multiple anode blocks in parallel within a single package—ESR and inductance (ESL) are further reduced, enabling better high-frequency performance.

Rectangular polymer aluminum chip capacitors employ layered anode foils connected in parallel, lowering ESR and ESL while supporting higher operating frequencies. This design provides a strong alternative to traditional tantalum capacitors.

Hybrid polymer aluminum electrolytic capacitors offer substantially lower leakage current than standard polymer aluminum capacitors, making them suitable for applications requiring tighter leakage specifications.

Polymer electrolytic capacitors are commonly used in power supplies for buffering, bypassing, and decoupling—especially in slim or compact devices. They compete with some ceramic capacitors but provide greater capacitance and avoid microphonic effects.

A variable capacitor allows intentional, repeated changes to its capacitance, either mechanically or electronically. This is typically done by adjusting the plate overlap area or the distance between the plates.

"Trimmer capacitors are small variable capacitors adjusted with a screwdriver—often used to fine-tune a circuit's resonance at the factory. They may use air, plastic, or even solid dielectrics like mica."

A butterfly capacitor is a rotary-style design featuring two separate stator plate sets and a rotor shaped like a butterfly. Rotating the rotor changes the overlap with each stator equally, varying the total capacitance. Because the rotor must have a fully non-overlapping position (minimum capacitance), it is usually limited to a 90° rotational range.

A split stator variable capacitor uses two rotor electrode assemblies placed axially behind one another, removing the 90° limit found in butterfly designs. Instead of multiple sections, each half of the rotor is mounted on opposite sides of the axis.

"Differential variable capacitors also include two independent stators. However, unlike a butterfly capacitor—where both sections increase in unison—one stator's capacitance grows while the other's diminishes, keeping the sum of both stators' capacitances constant."

Variable capacitors frequently appear in LC circuits for tuning a resonant frequency, such as in radio tuning (earning the name \"tuning capacitor\"), or to provide variable reactance in applications like antenna matching networks.

SMD (Surface-Mount Device) capacitors use compact codes to represent capacitance values in small components. These codes follow international standards to convey value, tolerance, and format effectively.
SMD capacitors use various coding systems, including three-digit, four-digit, and EIA codes. Each system follows a unique structure.
The three-digit code is commonly used for ceramic capacitors. The first two digits represent the significant figures, and the third digit is a multiplier. The equation is:
The four-digit code is very similar to the three-digit code, with the addition of a 4th value which indicates the tolerance.
"The letter 'R' indicates the position of the decimal point for capacitance values lower than 10 \u03A9. For example, 0R5 would be 0.5 \u03A9 and 0R01 would be 0.01 \u03A9."
The EIA-198 code uses a combination of letters and digits to encode capacitance values. The letter corresponds to the base capacitance value, and the digit is a multiplier.
